Service was a little off, but the food was delicious (and cheap!) Liked the atmosphere as well... and there is a live iguana for your viewing pleasure.

I am so excited that I finally found my favorite cafe, I love this place! They have a great menu with a large wine list and their coffee tastes amazing! I can't wait to come back for lunch or dinner, from what I could see from other tables, it all looks delicious!! PS I love pet iguana!

House hunting can make you thirsty.  While looking around in the hood, we decided to stop for a drink.  My English Breakie tea came in a large mug.  Hurrah for the environmental option!  The cafe really reminded me of a European coffee house.  I totally felt the vibe. Service was good.  I didn't eat any of the food but would definitely try it if I come back here.  Hopefully, I will since I really love the townhouse we found. Anyway, I was able to find street parking without a problem.   I didn't try the WiFi and was bummed to see tha tyou have to pay.

This place is a little behind Artopolis on their coffee drinks and desserts, but the food overall is quite satisfying.  Their baked pasta dish was great and their salmon salad was refreshing.  I like customizing my own sandwich here and they do have a great selection of meats and cheeses to choose from.

i absolutly love this place! The service is good, and the food is better. The Crepes are amazing, try the Amsterdam one, or any of the dessert ones that have nutella on them. The meatloaf samdwich was surprisingly tasty. And one of my favorite things to do is go there for drinks and the dips! the hummus, spicy feta dip and spinach dip are so yummy! Not to mention the awesome chai lattes. i can only hope that they let that live iguana out enough and give him lots of love, because this place deserves 5 stars all the way!

I miss European style coffee and tea houses, and this place comes pretty darned close to recreating the atmosphere for me.  Added bonus?  Umm, nutella (!!!!) but also some rocking teas and coffees.   The coffee drinks are always expertly crafted, but I mainly come here for Iguana's orange and currant teas.  The taste of these beverages is outstanding and reminds me of family get-togethers in cafes near my grandmother's house. Although this is a creperie, I must admit I have never tried Iguana's crepes.  The menu is diverse enough and the selections so tasty that I haven't quite worked my way down to the crepes. If you're in the mood for something small and savory, definitely try Iguana's hummus, cheesy crab dip, or baked goat cheese.  The portion sizes are big enough to split among friends or to have a meal on your own.  The tiropita and vegetarian wrap are also very satisfying. There are two reasons why Iguana doesn't get higher marks for me despite it's very low prices and high-quality beverages and food.  One, the place is cramped.  Tables are placed so very close together that sometimes I feel as if I am eating together with the people sitting next to me (so wait to hold your private conversations elsewhere). It is also difficult to distinguish between the section of the Cafe that is a cafe and the portion that is served by waitresses.  Second, while the wait staff and baristas are always extremely friendly and hospitable, the wait for a drink or your food sometimes takes a bit longer than normal.
Just stumbled in here for lunch and was pleasantly suprised! They have a great menu with something for everyone. The waitstaff was great we really enjoyed our food. Definitely will be back!

I read all the reviews from yelp and went very expectantly to Iguana cafe to have crepe for brunch but alas.... they don't serve crepe until 1:30PM. The waitress was downright rude when I asked her when the place closes. Anyway we ordered for a sandwich which was very good. The hot chocolate was great as well. Not just the food but the prices are great too.

I just ate a Nutelle + crushed cookie crepe, and it was absolutely incredible. I'm very, very picky about crepes too. Most I've had in the US haven't been up to my standards, but this one definitely did. The Nutella made the biggest difference because I always ate Nutella crepes in France. I recommend sharing one with one or maybe two people. Two of us could barely finish one! I am also drinking a mint mocha and it's pretty average. I don't care too much for the atmosphere. 1) there's a TV. 2) tables are close together. 3) the music isn't so great, in my opinion. I do like the art on the walls, the high ceilings, and the colors. I think this place achieves what it's going for though. It reminds me of European coffeehouses, but I'm just much more of a fan of comfy places with more character (in that they are more worn-in/not so fancy.)  But if you like fancy places and bathrooms with holes and writings on the wall would be uncomfortable, this place would be for you. My server told me the Wifi cost, but I got onto some random network that I'm guessing isn't their's.
I am a fan of this place.  The coffee is excellent and the crepes are very good.  The service sometimes is a little slow.

If there is one thing in life that I love to splurge on, its Nutella! I absolutely love, lovvvvve it!!!! And Iguana has plenty of it!! I've been to Iguana many times for a variety of things, mainly coffee on a late night, but I've never tried their crepes. This week, crepes were definitely on my mind. I managed to eat here twice this past week.  First visit I ordered a latte, creamy delicious potato soup and the 'Venice' - Fresh mozzarella, basil, tomatoes & roasted red peppers. It was huge and it was good! My 2nd visit I had already eaten a meal earlier, so I planned to just have dessert. I ordered a latte - so foamy and good, along with the 'Sweet Bee' - Nutella, honey & banana. It was massive, mouth drooling, amazing, fantastic!!!! My friend kept staring at it and asking for tastes. I cannot stress how good it was! The 'Sweet Bee' comes highly recommended to all who love Nutella.  Only one distraction - The iguana in the glass cage that lives in the lofted area. Should I feel bad for him? He is also massive in size and seemed eager to get out... I couldn't help but feel for him. Does he have a name? I hope he gets out often??

A friend introduced me Iguana several years ago. I don't live near it but its an easy trip on the blue line for me and its worth going out of the way for. Street parking also seems to be plentiful. There is a great, easy going atmosphere, very competent service, and I've never eaten a bad thing there. I crave their croissant breakfast sandwiches and amazing coffee drinks. The entrees are well portioned and well priced. I can see myself sitting there for hours with coffee and a book, if I lived in the neighborhood. Really love this place!

Too bright for a bar; too dark for a cafe.  What is this place?  We step in & it's like a bad Disaronno ad, right before the women at the bar slurp off the ice cube.  Normally, this wouldn't be so awful an image but it came off less like Playboy pay-per-view block being accidentally descrambled on your TV & more like walking in on your moms in a doggy style.  And worse, your momma doing the horizontal hoochie coo to drum 'n bass.  Drum 'n bass? Do people really still listen to this crap? Seriously.  Did I stumble upon the Le Passage after party?  Then, just when I thought I'd fallen into a time machine.... I look up to see  Lou "Build a fence around the border" Dobbs on a flat screen TV.  And Lou Dobbs is interviewing Ann Coulter and she's railing on that the Republican Party needs an attack machine.  Really? Who unwinds like this at a cafe? Newt Gingrich?  I try to order the simplest two items imaginable - lemonade and ice cream. Somehow two minutes later, I get a stein of iced tea. Whaa? On top of everything, the place is full of the most random people possible including a woman reading three GQ magazines over a drink ( I like Glenn O'Brien too, but not times three), a clueless couple laughing about using "food stamps" at Whole Foods, and a guy in a Rudy Lozano T-shirt. I wanted to throw them into a pop culture cage match. Maybe that's why it's so well lit and unusually tense in this odd place. It's the home for future tapings of MTVs "Non-Celebrity Death Match." As for my complicated meal, the lemonade was mostly lemon with little aid. The ice cream was passable. Hard to screw that up. So they didn't. I might have tried to order more except I didn't want to run into Karl Rove in search of a cappuccino.

Brightly colored walls with beautiful art all over the place to a slightly grating beat of non-stop drum and bass music.   I like that their offerings include a mix of coffee and nonalcoholic drinks, some booze, dessert and snacks - some of my favorite things.  But the execution is kind of off.  It's kind of hard to figure out where to sit if you are getting waitress service vs just getting yourself a cup of coffee and sitting down on your own, because all of the seating is lumped together.  They could use some soft chairs and more comfy seating arrangements, instead of just hard chairs and small cafe tables. My food was pretty average and a bit overpriced.  My crepe was tough and I didn't finish it - and I rarely leave food to waste (exhibit a - my ass).  I'd come back and try it again, but I wouldn't go out of my way - just gave me a general sense of trying to hard. ALERT: If you are looking to find your own personal Oprah vajayjay moment, go to the bathroom here.  There is a full length, floor length mirror right in front of the toilet.  Oh. Hello there! Wow....

I love this place!  I once spent 3 hours there!!!  The appetizers are delicious.  But I can't say much for the entrees since I've always ordered the smoked salmon salad, and trust me, that salad is to die for. The coffee is great too but quite strong so don't drink too much towards the evening.  This is definitely a place to check out for it's unique atmosphere and feel.

I went here with my friends tonight after reading some Yelp reviews. I was not disappointed at all! For an appetizer, we got the baked goat cheese. It's baked goat cheese and marinara with a thin crustini-like bread. Delish.  For an entree I got the carbanara pasta, then for desert I got the caramel creation crepe.  I was not disappointed in any of the dishes.  Also, we had 3 different people helping our table, and there were only 3 of us.  The tables are pretty close together, but like many have said before, the place is very European, so it should be expected.  Overall, this place is fab! My friends and I made a unanimous decision to work Iguana in as one of the places we frequent.  I highly, highly recommend!!

We have been driving by this place since we moved here from San Diego and never really gave it a second thought till a few weeks ago.  This place is an excellent departure from your standard chaos filled attempts to eat breakfast or brunch anyplace in this entire city except for the exceptionally few spots like this one. We got there around 12.30 or so on a Saturday and had no problem finding a place to sit.  The menu skews towards the crapes they make but there are other sandwiches and salads to choose from.  They also have a full bar and standard coffee choices, I was a little let down that there are no refills on regular coffee but whatever. We both got sandwiches which were tasty in their own right and a minestrone soup.  Soup was just o.k. and would have been good with some shaved cheese on top or something.  Next time I'm definitely getting a crape. All around tasty but there are definitely some spots they could improve such as fresh juices which I didn't notice anywhere on the menu.  Definitely a fan though and will be back for sure.   RrL
I once had a really awkward first date here. I had a vodka tonic. He had a sandwich. The drink was strong enough to get me through the pain. 4 stars!

Very unique coffee spot in West Loop. Love the crepes, the atmosphere, and the Euro feel. I could sit here all day and "work" or people watch. It's so much better now since the smoking ban. My only gripe is the sometimes absent minded staff. Other than that, great spot for catching up over coffee and crepes or "work" duties.

How do you say, um, concrete good?   Love this place, and recently stopped by for a pre-dinner drink.   Hot with a cool vibe.   Not a place to showcase your formal French training or haute-cuisine ambitions...just a place to sit back and chill with friends, your book, or your drink.   Coffee, or a martini, wine, or a chamomile tea.   Delicious crepes, sandwiches, salads, a full menu with plenty of vegetarian options, and extremely reasonable prices.    It's a great late-night place open until midnight during the week and until 2am on weekends...excellent service.   I would prefer it if Iguana was closer to home.... I would easily become a regular here.

I lived by here for a year and half and never went. I always wanted to. I really should have. Add two years to the clock and I'm back in town with some friends when we decide to swing by after gorging ourselves at La Scorola. A little pick-me-up Iguana caramel something-or-other and a peanut butter and gnutella crepe later...I couldn't move, but I was oh-so-happy! I live in Seattle now, and this place reminded me of all the great coffee shops there. Trendy. Tasty. You should go.

I've never know a coffee house to refuse customers for business during their normal hours of operation. But I guess there is a first for everything. At 1:40 AM my brother and I decided to stop in for a quick hot cocoa. Upon entering I noticed an employee (possibly the manager) look at his watch after seeing us enter. After he shook his head in that typical "gah last minute customer" style... I asked him if it was ok if we grab a quick drink. He said no everything is shut down. This was a bit odd being that on the door said they were closed at 2 AM. I am giving them 1 star at this time because of the lack of service and inconsistent communication between the signage on the door and what the staff actually expects to work till. Clearly if you want to grab a drink you need to do so before 1:15 AM on Saturday as to not inconvenience the staff.

A friendly neighborhood cafe and wine bar that I wish was more common in the city.  The staff is welcoming and provide a friendly and hospitable atmosphere.  The obvious stand outs are the coffee drinks and the crepes.  Ever try the bougatsu?  Want some, get some.   I'm not a smoker, but I kind of miss the days when there was a smoking section.  It definitely gave Iguana that European character.

This place has the coolest atmosphere of any cafe I've been to in Chicago yet.  I definitely dig the late-night euro vibe.  Dimly lit, subdued electronic/trance music, and beautiful people that look like they're only stopping here amid their weekly commute between Chicago and...the Mediterranean.  The coffee drinks are good-I wouldn't say anything spectacular but good.  Frappes, chais, of course espresso...the standard varieties of a euro cafe.  One thing that did bug me (being a coffee nut) were the specialty drinks that didn't give descriptions of ingredients...and I was too lazy to ask about.  Going as late as I usually do, I don't usually eat, but what I have had has always been excellent.  Appears to be a good setup for lunch, too; large windows overlooking Halsted, and I believe free wifi.  Definitely my favorite place to go when I haven't shaved for 2 days, and feel like wearing a black shirt and $250 jeans  :)  Not that it's snobbish by any means, but that's the easiest way to blend in!  To be clear, though, I really, really, really love the atmosphere of this place!

Very European indeed, service included- meaning it's a bit slow.  Other than that, I love this place.  And just like in Europe, you can forgive the slower service because the drinks are tall, the food is good, and you fit right in no matter who you are.  Great place to sit a while and do work or just sit and people watch (or you can watch the single TV that always seems to be on, but muted).   I do feel bad for the real live Iguana though, that's the true reason I can't give this place five stars.

I felt the need to update my review since I have visited Iguana Cafe a few more times with my (now) fiance. I've tried something different each time from the menu and each time the food is more delicious than the last. The raspberry mocha latte is still the best part, but then again I live on coffee and merely survive on food. Saying that, the food is awesome. Zach M is right about the pasta salad. They use too much oil when ordered as a main rather than a side dish. But food-wise that's my only real complaint.  That and the fact that there isn't a bad thing on the whole menu and it takes me aaages to decide on what to enjoy each time. But such is life. The iguana is oddly cute and when conversation lapses, iguana watching or commenting on the Med-inspired art on the walls are good topic renewers. The service is slightly above average but still not amazing and the music can be a tad too loud occasionally, but I generally don't mind either fact. I'm moving back to England soon, so I need to find a way to transport this place and pronto!!!

Food is incredible. Coffee drinks are excellent. Environment is unique to Chicago - very European, quiet, and elegant. Studying capabiltiies are questionable only because the circular tables are a bit awkward and the pay-for internet is expensive.

Still love it.  I set up my "office" here today for several hours of meetings. My only gripe was the parking situation, as I purposefully picked this place because it has daytime parking, and all of the exits were blocked by construction or cars. BUGGER. I think my meter ate about $8! Anyway. The food, phenomenal for the price. For breakfast I had the salmon, creme cheese and cuke bagel. It might be my most favorite breakfast of all time now...and $4.25. Seriously? It was like a Philly roll with a bagel instead of seaweed. Totally stellar. Toasted bagel, semi-melty cream cheese, long slices of crispy cucumber and fresh, raw salmon. Delightful. It rescued my haphazard morning.  Coffee: LARGE, and in a real mug. Thank you, heaven. Real cream that billows (the sign of freshness, so I'm told). Splenda. Recipe for success.  Lunch (told you I was here for a long time!) was a caesar salad with chicken, which was large, with fresh chix chunks, fresh cheese and toasty croutons, with a side of dressing. Really fresh and tasty...$6.25.  Really, the food is an outstanding value for what it is. Great service, laid back Euro coffeehouse feel.  NO FREE WIFI. (it is available, you just have to pay).  Mmmm, love the iguana forever.

I was raised in the sticks where you sit down in any diner and the waitress calls you, "hun, baby, sweetheart," and all those nice pet names for the transients that stop in for that short moment of life. Doesn't mean your special, it's just very comforting - like you've found a momentary shelter from the harsh world and you can relax and drink your coffee and eat your grits. I felt right at home at Iguana Cafe. The only things that gave away the fact that I wasn't back home in the sticks; the waitress had a nice European accent when she called me "hun, baby, sweetheart", There were crepes on the list instead of grits, you could get your coffee spiked with something other than the flask of Jack Daniels that you carried in.  Great place to eat, have a drink, have a coffee, listen to music, eavesdrop, feel at home, study (make sure you get a spot with a light though, kinda dark)...

Love, love, LOVE this place. I've been with a group of friends, on a date, lunch with a business Associate, lunch with a girlfriend, and just by myself and my laptop. Great atmosphere, great service and they serve alcohol if you are so inclined.

The lunch choices around my work is sparse to say the least but I've been able to find some gems nonetheless. Iguana Cafe is definitely one of my favorites and I recently tried them for an after dinner visit. I got a good tasting cup of coffee and tried a Nutella and Banana crepe which tasted yummy and was more than enough. During my visits for lunch, I usually get a panini style sandwich which also comes out tasting good. So with all the good quality food I've had, the prices are very reasonable. I also love the euro-feel of this place as it is very laid back. The staff is very friendly and attentive yet if the place is busy, they may be a touch slow but no big deal as this place is a laid back cafe.

Very nice.  Kind of swank, but also very comfortable.  This place has a unique cool vibe.  It works well as a nightime meet and eat spot, but I could also see it as a nice neigborhood hangout-and-read type of place when the light is shining.  I came here at night, pre-bar and had some very delicious pizza bread.  My friend, seemingly cannot stop raving about her Hummus wrap, (which is a accomplishment as I can't imagine eating straight up hummus without falafel or something).  Food is nice, kind of a standard coffee, sandwich, drink cooler, walk up setup.  But also has a nice seating area (reminded me of college coffeehouse actually) off to the side with waiter/waitress service.  Food selection is nice and large.  Based off the food I've seen I'd say it was really good.  Prices are very nice.  Nice to have a nice but casual place to eat in this spot, since its surrounded by mostly bars.  I can only imagine iguana is set up to cater to the bar crowd, since there aren't many apartments or such in the nieghborhood.  Its not really a type of "destination" type of place, but I'd imagine this would make a great neighborhood coffeehouse or lunch spot if you happen to be close by.

As I sit here at work on a Saturday...yes, a Saturday...I can't stop thinking about Iguana Cafe! I stumbled upon this lovely, European-ish cafe last night after a friend & I arrived too early to go into the Butterfly Social Club. I must admit, I'm quite glad we did. It's a bit dark inside & a kind of strange menu, but it reminds me of my good ol' days of cafes in Europe so I can't really complain. As I just said the menu is strange, but very large so it seems as if there would be something for everyone. It ranges from salads & soups to crepes. Trust me, everything sounded delish! I ended up with the hummus wrap, which was unreal. It was the perfect mixture of red pepper hummus, feta cheese, and tomatoes. Oh my Lord, I'm drooling...thank goodness no one else in the office! My friend had the pizza bread, which I thought was pretty good (bacon, green peppers, tomatoes, cheese). I wish this place wasn't so far from my casa because this would definitely be a place I would go to regularly & try something new every time!

The only thing I knew to expect going in was a friend meeting my wife and I for lunch. The vibe is pretty cool at this cafe. The food's fresh, the music is similar to Starbuck's selection and the motife is definitely an earthy, folkloric setting for a place to eat. Since my new friend was raving about the Mint Iced Coffee so much I decided to give it a shot. I think she was high on her own estrogen because anybody could have made this drink. The lunch I ordered was great. Sorry but I don't remember the sandwich I ate right now. The ingredients were fresh and I do remember enjoying the flavor of this delicious sandwich. If you want a suprising tasty meal for a moderate price and lay back for a while go to this restaurant. The staff is friendly. I've read they even have free wifi here. Nice!

This place totally reminds me of the Gypsy Den back in Orange County, CA. This place has that earthy, artsy, beatnik kind of feel.  They serve up a wide variety of sandwiches, crepes, desserts, and coffee drinks.  I had the turkey ranch wrap which was delicious. I had the mint mocha latte which was ok. I also had a very tasty strawberry, banana, and nutella crepe.  Our waitress was friendly and attentive. I'll definitely be coming back here again.  It's affordable, quick, and delicious.

This place is awesome. Nice atmosphere, good music, open late, great food, nice drink selection, and WIFI. It's great for hanging out by yourself or with one or two other people. Not good for large groups.
no matter what time i head to the iquana- i always love it .. breakfast, lunch.  .. afternoon snack.  .. light dinner.  .. evening cocktail.  ..  .. lately i love the meatloaf sandwich!

OK! I'm not going to lie, I've passed this place many times and always thought the sign said Lguana, which, I had no idea what that meant. As my recent review for KOK or KOKO should I say, I should probably get glasses or learn how to read better. I was introduced to Iguana cafe by my friend Dion who loves to come here for coffee and crepes. We came after class one day and I was blown away by their decor. I felt like I could have been in Europe!  We ordered the nutella crepes with bananas (as you can tell my favorite thing to order) and he ordered a red eye, which I guess is coffee with a shot of espresso? Something crazy like that, but he definitely confessed later he didn't go to bed anytime soon that night. Our crepe was so delicious, nice and soft, chewy and chocolatey! (They don't serve crepes till after 1:30, which I don't get... they should change that)  I've come back here 2 more times since he's taken me and ordered the cheesy crab dip (it's crab stick but who cares it's so good) and their sandwiches which come with a great pasta salad. Their menu offers all that I want in a lunch or snack craving. I look forward to trying their baked pasta and the rest of the items on the menu! Everything is reasonably priced, which is so hard to find these days. Oh, and just so you don't freak out or say I didn't tell ya so, there's a live iguana in a cage above the dining area. I thought it was fake till it moved. Enjoy!

Not too many such European style cafes in Chicago.  Serves breakfast lunch and dinner, and is open late. Downside is it does not open very early on weekends (everyone's gotta sleep some time). Service is friendly but 'relaxed,' except for to-go orders, in which case this place fits the bill.  Right across from Blue Line entrance means you won't miss your train.  Food and beverage quality is good. Their croissant sandwiches are tasty and reasonable. I was glad to see it survived ramp-up period while the neighborhood was coming into its own.

Most places in Europe combine coffee and liquor; in the morning/afternoon you go there for a cappuccino and then in the evening for a cocktail or glass of wine. Iguana keeps well to this tradition and also offers a decent food selection. I'm not sure their entrees are worth going out of your way to come here, but all the food is very reasonably priced and their crepes are above average. Their spicy feta dip (tirokafteri) is really good. I also enjoy the atmosphere. It's very well-decorated and is trendy enough to be out of the ordinary but not pretentious. People seem to come here just to hang out and chat, and there is never anybody over 45 or under 20 (these are pluses for me). It is also open relatively late (2ish). One thing they need to do though is get rid of the TV. A drink, something to eat, and a coffee will be under $20.

A very cool and chill place for an afternoon lunch. I have been a couple times and always walk away pleased. The hummus plate is nice and the sandwiches are great. I recently got the greak sandwich, and even being full after eating the whole thing I could of had another...it was that good. They have an awesome selection of vegetarian options. If you're on your way into work in the morning they also offer a good amount of coffee options for you to get your fix.

We wanted dessert and when we realized La Sardine was closed, we decided to head home. While cabbin' back to Old Town we were driving along on Halsted and saw Iguana Cafe and decided to stop in for dessert. As everyone has already stated, the lounge/cafe is very Euro and I enjoyed it. I definitely could see myself coming to this place with my laptop and just vege with a fantastically large and creamy latte.  So anyways, I ordered a delicious cafe latte and my dude and I split dessert. It was fantastic. Can't wait to stop by again!

Stopped by for my friend's birthday party. A relaxed cozy place with ambient inside space but with small tables and makes it comfortable and place to interact. Definitely european, food and service is great.  They even accomodated our group reqeust to check the Basketball score on the TV they have.  Tried the relaxing tea, and waiting to try the lipsmacking crepes or the sandwiches(Meatloat, veggie or tuna/salmon).   From my less than hour experience, they did a good job.

I have had many late night lattes at this joint. It's such a great alternative to the cookie-cutter-on-every-corner-coffee-shop. Especially if you want to just lounge and have a great cup of coffee and some pretty good apps/sandwiches.  But I am disappointed.... I've never tried the crepes that everyone is raving about!  Don't worry...next visit, I'm all over them!
I loved this place the first two times I went, but went there last night and the food was utterly disgusting :(.  So sad.  Anyways, I'll stick to it for drinks.

I was so happy to discover this place in my back yard.  Delicious-- I mean DELICIOUS crepes-- the best I've had since I lived in Paris.  And they're huge-- I couldn't even eat half of mine.  Perhaps that was because I had already stuffed my face with an assortment of tasty dips from the appetizer menu.  The prices are great-- very affordable.  The atmosphere is big, airy, and warm, and the tables were small, which I like for that intimate, cozy cafe feel.  The service was really good too.  I plan on becoming a regular here.   I drove past Iguana Cafe on my way back home after an evening out, and it seemed people were still hanging out having cocktails close to 2 am, so I'll have to go back for that experience soon. Just a note-- don't bother going here for breakfast-- you can't get the crepes until the afternoon, and their breakfast croissants are just so-so.

This little Euro-style Coffee shop  is a nice little spot to grab a cup of coffee and some top-notch crepes. Not the coolest coffee shop in the world, but definitely worth a stop. Not a bad alternative to staying in at the apartment. Not a bad alternative to the bars. Not a bad alternative to anything. Check it out.

I like you.  I'd like you more if your service wasn't so slow.  But I still like you and your dark interior.  I also like that you're big inside and make decent lattes.  I like pretending I'm in Europe whenever I visit you.  I also like how you don't mind that I do that.  But I don't like how I feel a pretentious vibe whenever I visit you.

This place is very wanna be Euro.  Not in the bad service kind of way, LOL, but in the loungey, I don't really have to be at work/school/appointment I am just lounging around in the middle of the work day and it's all good kind of way.   The food is good. I always stick to the tried and true meatloaf sandwich.  It comes on a sesame bread with mayo, roasted red peppers and cheese.  Then, it's put in the panini maker and it comes out awesome.   If you don't love meatloaf, try the Mediterranean sandwich, which is all veggie.  Want fish? Try the salmon sandwich. Can you tell I've only had the sandwiches here?   They do have other things, and the pasta in the clay pot looked really good, but for me, Iguana's not really that kind of place. If you are nearby, it's worth a visit.  Just don't look like you have to be somewhere....you'll stand out.

On a warm spring day in Chicago all I wanted was a huge ice coffee...and I found myself a tasty one at this cozy cafe.  I ordered the mocha, raspberry iced latte and it sure hit the spot! Definitely on the sweet side, but that's just how I like my lattes.  My companion ordered just a regular iced latte and had to add lots of sugar to hers....any more sugar in mine and I would have been climbing the walls. Service was just OK. We had to ask our waitress a few times for the check and it probably wouldn't have hurt the girl to crack a smile. A 75 degree day in Chicago is definitely something to smile about, although then again I wouldn't be smiling much if I was stuck inside on a gorgeous spring day. I'll be back for more caffeine and next time look forward to trying their food...

This place is great! I swear it was one of the reasons we bought our condo across the street! It's cozy, eclectic and has a cool vibe. Whether you want breakfast, great coffee or a margarita, this place always delivers. The menu isn't huge, but what they have is good. Everyone raves about the spinach pie, I don't particularly like it, too dry. But I do love their baked goat cheese, yum!  It has a small coffee house/European-ish type feel to it. There's always good, chill music playing and interesting art displayed. I would definitely recommend the "Lizard" as it's referred to in our house.

The most outstanding crepes that I have ever eaten.  I was born and raised in Paris and I never thought I would say this about any other place but France, I found heaven when I ate a Crepe here.  The last bite was just a good as the first.  Later on, I couldn't resist, I ordered a dessert crepe with Nutella chocolate & fruit, and a latte to wash it down.  I almost embarrassed myself by licking the plate, however, I contained myself knowing that I would be back for more very soon.  I have to be back, while looking thru the menu I noticed a variety of appetizers that seemed very appealing and would go great with a glass of wine.  I truly like the environment, it had a very European feeling with friendly people.  I am glad I discovered this place and would recommend it to all.

I have visited the Iguana Cafe many, many times. It is near my place of employ, and I'm terribly lazy when it comes to feeding myself. Therefore, I feel like I can comprehensively assess its highs, its lows and its competencies. 1) The food could have a bit more range- it all boils down to just sandwiches, salads and pasta, viewed more or less through a Mediterranean lens. I really enjoy the vegetarian sandwiches, and the potato salad is weirdly good.* The pasta is great --really great-- but comes baked in huge portions and covered with cheese. Poison.   2) The drinks are delicious and they always serve you in a big ceramic mug, so as to say, "Stay a while, stranger." 3) This is the best place to bring a country mouse who would like to experience a bit of your city mouse life. The Iguana Cafe is supposed to be European, and it feels thusly, to a degree. It is really quite beautiful and relaxing on the inside and very rarely overcrowded. The clientele tends to be attractive and lead mysterious lives of intrigue. You too can be part of that mystery.  I would be remiss to exclude the fact that there is an actual iguana -which, admittedly, is kind of awesome-- but also remiss if I failed to note that he has to be sad and lonely in his aquarium. Free the Iguana Cafe Iguana! *All my food evaluations should be taken with the understanding that I don't really like food-- certainly not good food; I'm writing this after licking Cheetos orangeness off the tips of my fingers.

Went here on Valentine's Day with the girls from work. Great food, and after our meals, they brought out free desserts! There's nothing 5 single girls love more on V-Day than some free tiramisu, chocolate cake, and ice cream! Loved it!

The place was kinda cool in a not-so-great eurotrash way. The PDA order taking was novel until they fucked up our order three times and were obstinate about fixing it. The food was just average. The cappuccino was more of a latte but the coconut sorbet was rockin..

Very cool place.  I'm not much of a coffee drinker, but this really isn't your catch-all coffee shop.  This is the only place like it here in Chicago - at least that I've found.  There are some other nice, cool independent cafes out there, but none with Iguana's vibe.   I guess it suits a certain type as well.  People will probably say its very euro, but I don't know about that.  I've seen euro and yeah, the guys who own and run the place are probably from somewhere in Europe, but this is like US-morphed euro or something like it.  And by that I mean better. They're open late on the weekends, almost 2, I think, but check that.  On the weekends it's almost a lounge with the music they play.  Some mild house and electronic stuff, but not too loud so you can talk.  Thing is, so many people will come to hang out, it actually can get pretty loud on the weekend. If you're not feeling the club or bar vibe on the weekend, go here with some friends, or even by yourself.  Bring a book, your laptop (WiFi not free, sorry) or some work, I don't know.  I've done that, and found myself people watching, and the place getting pretty busy. Food is okay cafe fare.  Coffee and drinks are the same as any other place, nothing outstanding, but not bad at all - and they have alcohol, so this place really is a great spot for a lot of things.  Also a good place to go during the day for business coffee, a date, meet a friend halfway in the middle of the loop for a chat, whatever. There's also an iguana way up high somewhere, hence the name, but I seriously only noticed it after the 20th time going there. Iguana Cafe - cool place to kick it if you just don't want to be in your house that night.  They'll let you stay all night long and not bother you either.

Yes, another 4 star review!  I hope that some day, some where I'll be super-wowed enough to drag my mouse over that  fifth star. There's lots to like about the place itself- original artwork and live plants and requisite exposed brick and duct work.  They even have a live iguana in a cage way up high where you can't pet or eat it.   I got a custom made panini that was perfectly cromulent.  The highlight?  The potato salad on the side!  It was not only passable, it was enjoyable.  Also delicious was the sausage that came with the antipasto.  Not so much the smarch tomatoes, not Iguana's fault they were flavorless but a winter substitution wouldn't have been amiss.   Oh yeah- the wait staff seems to take orders on some kind of futuristic electronic pad, just like they do on the enterprise or at fedex.

Maybe it was the live Iguana located above the bar, delicious coffee or the art deco style, but this place quickly became a favorite. It's boast of being a Europeen-style cafe is apt, as the quaint tables, hip vibe, raised ceilings, studioesque openness reminded me of cafes in Paris and Brussels. The House Blend coffee was rich, and their Mocha had a pleasant cocoa bite.  The gourmet ice cream and hot fudge sundae were brilliant.  As far as real food, their Bruschetta was desiredly crisp, liberally layered with olive oil, prociutto, and fresh feta. Iguana's also has all of Chicago's alt-weeklies, including my New City. The only thing I wish they had was free wireless, then I'd spend hours there.  However, you can usually find a weak connection by stealing it from one of the neighbors.    Iguana's is a must-see. I'll have to check out their regular bar at night.

When I lived in the neighborhood, Iguana Cafe was my home away from home.  What a great spot to sip on a latte, write, read, eat a Mediterranean sandwich, people watch, meet a handsome Italian man, order the wine, share a dessert, finish with Cappuccino, finally notice that said Italian man isn't wearing deodorant... yes, I've actually spent a day turned to evening here. Great fodder for that unraveling novella.  Or the backdrop for that poster child Indie romance.  Oh, I love it here! I've tried the wraps, but the sandwiches are much better.  The Nutella crepe is also a staple.  And the baked goat cheese-- frankly, I'd order it more if I wasn't downsizing.   In any case, Iguana Cafe is good stuff.  And though it's a pain, I still make the trek from Lakeview sometimes.  But now it's a weekends only love affair.

I really do want to like this place more - the interior is quite nice and I love the late hours. But the food is just...not good. Everything is always bland and the vegetables are either not that fresh or not prepared right - I can't tell. I tried ordering Greek food in the hopes that it would be more their thing, and it STILL wasn't good. I was trying to study there but the waitress kept coming by every 15 minutes, asking whether she could get me something else. I hadn't even finished my food or coffee! It was really irritating and we finally left because of it. The music's also a bit off - techno on a Sunday afternoon? No thanks.

this place is great. good food, great coffee/teas, awesome martini's. very euro-cafe atmosphere. they do have a parking lot next to the cafe and its right across the street from grand stop blue line.  staff is super friendly, and you feel like your at home. i recommend the paninis. there delicious.

I liked the place but can't say I'd go out of my way to come back here. I thought it was all cozy and comfortable and whatnot, but the hot cocoa I ordered just tasted like something from a mix that I could have made at home... and it wasn't real hot, either, so I had to drink it fast before it got cold. The coffee that others ordered was good, not great. One person ordered theirs with raspberry flavoring and they either didn't add enough or forgot it altogether. We didn't eat anything here so I can't comment on the food, but the offerings in the menu looked pretty appealing.

This place is pretty cool, but it's not in the most bumpin' part of the city.  It does have a real iguana in a case high up on the wall and was playing Fight Club when I went.  It looked like this guy who had a front row seat, came to watch the movie.  It's best described as a bar/coffee-house and my buddy really liked their coffee.  They also have decently priced food (sandwiches, quesadillas, deserts, etc). It is waitress service, if that bothers you...

This European cafe is pretty good. The atmosphere is very warming and comfortable. This is the place to go if you want to talk to a couple of friends or with your date. Remember to order their crepes on the menu, it is by far one of the best crepes we had in Chicago. Prices are very reasonable. Their coffees are also comparable to the ones from Starbucks.  Surprisingly it might even taste better than the ones in starbucks. The waitresses were very polite and friendly. I will definitely visit this place again. And yes they sell liquor and wine. :D

Very cute.  People really leave you alone in there, which I love.  It's not a place to mingle.  It's a place to get coffee with your friend and be quiet and bring your laptop or a newspaper. Good coffee.  Decent appetizers.   I think they claim to be comparable to a European coffee house.  I would say that this claim is correct. I like it.

This place is probably great if you're a regular (and when smoking was still allowed) but I went there for a late Sunday dessert run and I felt as if I was missing the secret password.  Blank stares, no menu posted and no prices posted.  We had a cake which had some cheese in it which probably required refrigeration.  I'll return to try a real sit down meal, but my first endeavor left me a little sour.

Really cute European and Greek cafe open late (until 12:30am!). They serve Intelligentsia coffee and have very skilled baristas. What's more, they serve liquor and wine so whether you're on a date, catching up with a friend, or in a group...everyone can find something here.  I love their grilled Mediterranean sandwiches, dim lighting, huge French windows, seat yourself pay at the front philosophy, fresh crepes, gelato, tiramisu,etc.  They even have a live iguana hanging out in a tank.  Oh, and Erica has got it down...this place is totally the spot where that the Coupling crew hangs out.
The best crepes!  The place is packed with such diverse, hip & young people during the weeknights!  The only thing that sucks is parking!

Okay so we all reviewed and loved Iguana, but I was just sad that I never gave a 5-star to one of my favorite cafes in the city.   Cool vibe, great service, fun customers, nice bathrooms, good location ... wine ... wine ... wine. Sometimes hard to park, but these are things you learn to live with.  I would put this on my list of great first date place ... I think I took one here ... and he was great ... great.

What a wonderful cafe!  I went here one night with a bunch of my friends when we didn't feel like going to a bar, and it was a great alternative.  It totally reminded me of being in Europe.  Being able to order a beer first then have tea and delicious tiramisu later.  It's an all around good place anytime of the day.  And there is an actual iguana.

[Check.. check.. is this thing on?  Sing-A-Long  to "My Favorite Things" from the Sound of Music.  Happy Holidays!] Coffee or Lattes or Cocktails at eight, Drinking at Iguanas is simply quite great. "Welcome, sit down!" they most certainly sing, These are a few of my favorite things. Proscuitto Sandwiches- your choice of bread, Goat cheese and hummus and crepes with a spread, Pasta Al Forno, the gourmet ice cream, These are a few of my favorite things. Greek Village Salads and soup of the day, Paired with a merlot- I'm feeling ok! Bruscetta, Bougatsa, Spinach Pie with cheese, These are a few of my favorite things. Some bleak morning, Will my day bring? Iguana's makes me glad! I simply remember my favorite things And then I don't feel so bad!

Great place to grab a bite, have a drink, or just get some coffee.  The staff are very friendly.  They've got awesome breakfast wraps to cure any hangover and tasty specialty sandwiches (smoked salmon, veggie wrap, italian, etc) although they're pretty small for $7.  Good desserts too.  Only real downside for me is the coffee - too weak for me personally and often  tastes burnt.

I love this place.  I've been coming here since 2001 and it has steadily evolved all the while.  I really can't think of another place in the city that I am equally happy going to for breakfast, lunch, dinner, or just a glass of wine.    The owner is really nice and the staff are all helpful too.  A few have been there since they opened. Their vinaigrette is awesome, great breakfast croissants, and the mediterranean  sandwich is also great.  The nutella croissant is so wrong, but soooo good. Good wine selection and a good atmosphere to boot. I almost forgot, if you like strong and sweet coffees try the Iguana Special.  Its realllly good.

I have been coming here since the day they opened.  Six years and two kids later, I still go for the best breakfast sandwich in town, great frappe, and crepes.  Remote order entry system used by wait staff means food is ready fast.  There's no kids' menu or crayons, but they gladly accommodate with small portions on request. The speedy service and casual environment makes for a kid-friendly experience.

Great late night spot that isn't diner-y. But it's good any time of the day. The service is good, although there's one waitress who seems to have been there forever who never smiles. The food is good too. They have great crepes, sandwiches and appetizers. It's always a go to spot for my group of friends when we're looking for a place to chill.

I've been looking for a good place in the hood to chill, study, and drink coffee that is open past 7p...  this place fits the bill.  The coffee is good the atmosphere is conducent to relaxing, studying, chilling out.  The place has a nice LCD with ESPN or other sports on.  The staff is laid back, the service is good.  Downside, no free wifi and it allows smoking.  Overall good place to relax and chill and its open late!

Lounge, coffee shop, study hall, wine bar, sports bar?  what are you, Iguana?  You're more like a chameleon.  You are whatever I want you to be.   Quiet enough, yes.  Smoky, yes.  Staff foreign, yes.   Snooty, sort of. Cheap, yes.

This place is great!  Went for the first time on Sunday for brunch and loved the vibe.  Totally chill, very euro...hang out as long as you want and nobody will bother you.  The mimosa was decent but my bagel with cream cheese, lox and cucumber was phenom - especially considering it was not a penny over $4.50.  The servers are a little on the slow side, but the clientele is great.

I found this place in 2005 when visiting a friend in the neighborhood.  He's since moved away and I've since moved to the neighborhood.  The one thing that remains constant is Iguana.  It's my kitchen away from home.  I can go at all hours of the day and get just what my stomach desires in a relaxed, very friendly atmosphere. While I don't work here, I might as well.  I've been known to eat here several times a week when I'm not traveling.  I have to have been here over 50 times in 2007 and I can honestly say I've never been disappointed once.  That speaks volumes given all of the choices here in Chicago. So here are the particulars: AMBIANCE:  This is a very cool space.  The exposed brick pulls the whole thing together and reinforces the European coffee house vibe.  Not too bright and not too dark.  One thing I will mention is it really is several restaurants in one. If you come for breakfast or lunch during the week you'll find folks who work in the neighborhood who want good food quickly.  If you come at night you'll find the candles on the table and find people lingering over coffee or wine.  If you come on the weekend you'll find the big weekend paper and lots of coffee crowd.  So if you come and the atmosphere isn't quite your cup of tea, give Iguana a try at another time of day. Also, the place is very international and you'll find people speaking all kinds of languages.  The owners are Greek (hence some of the food) and the servers are from all over.  Having traveled as much as I have, I find that to be a real 'plus'. The only possible drawback in this category is the smoking.  It's really not that bad, but I'm not used to smelling like smoke anymore when I go eat anywhere.  (It's technically a bar and smoking is still allowed).  This is really a moot point as the new Illinois state law takes place on January 1. SERVICE:  I have always found the service to be efficient.  If you want to chat them up, they're happy to chat back.  However, their primary concern is that you sit back and relax in their 'living room'.  Get comfortable.  If you do, you'll be back again and again. FOOD:  The food really is the star here.  I've tried many, many things on the menu and have never been disappointed.  The quality is always very good.  The breads and the deserts are worth special mention for their freshness and quality.  If you like Greek and or Mediterranean food, those are always a good bet.  There are also plenty of things on the menu for the Vegetarians among us. It is a coffeehouse, after all, and the coffee is quite solid and the range of coffee drinks quite extensive.  There is also a full bar and a very nice selection of wines by the glass that changes now and again.  My current favorite is the organic Malbec.  At $7 a glass, this is a nice value. So, I strongly encourage you to give Iguana a try.  Take some friends and while away the time amidst the great coffee and fine food.  Or, go alone and be prepared to meet some of the most interesting people in Chicago.  Either way, be prepared to get comfortable.  If you do, I know you'll be back.
All I came in for was coffee and a cigarette. The coffee was decent, the music was very disagreeable and my server was snooty and cold. Needless to say I won't be returning anytime soon.

I am on an incessant quest to find the perfect Sunday NYTimes reading spot.  As cafes can get busy on the weekends, I like to have a few options available to me.  And it always seems that my favorite places have a few things in common: space to sit, great coffee, laid back vibe, and the option of a late afternoon glass of wine.  And back in LA, it would have had al fresco dining/seating...but I suppose I can't have it all, can I? (Can you imagine that?  It takes a good couple of hours to get through that tome of a paper and add to that, the brazenly blistering sun of LA, and a couple of glasses of wine?  Sounds like a disaster made in heaven to me....)  Iguana has it all (except for the al fresco thing...so apparently, I can't have it all).  Not only does it possess all of the aforementioned, but it also has a great selection of breakfast/brunch options and is open late for dinner/desserts.  I find the service there a perfect combination of being there when you need something and not when you don't.  Your water glass gets filled without you even noticing and I don't feel pestered as I while away the hours.  Don't get me wrong though, I try to consume/buy enough to make my time worth Iguana's while.     It's a perfect place to grab brunch with a friend, read the paper/a book or study by yourself, or get a drink with a group of people.  And as opposed to some of the more northerly establishments, the crowd is a bit more diverse than the Abercrombie-clad patrons who are further north.  The clientele consists of everyone from families with kids to older folks to neighborhood locals to young couples to eccentrics to uber-fantastic gals like me.     It's too bad I found this place so early on since my move from LA to Chicago because I don't want to look any further.

I have been here once, we ordered the goat cheese appetizer and when it came out it was still cold so we told the waitress so then she brings it out and it was burning hot! I thought it was pretty good but they only give you so much toasted bread to eat it with and I thought that was kinda stale.... I had a vegertarian sandwich which I do not recommend it, it was very bland.... My boyfriend got the pasta, which was actually not bad.... Our service was really bad too....

Met up here with Yelp connoisseur Leang for a light dinner on a Tuesday night. Iguana has a definite European vibe- within vicinity of our table I could hear Polish, Greek and even a bit of English:) The technoish Jazz and foreign tongues created a feeling reminiscent of Vienna or Prauge.  I ordered a Greek Salad with feta, cucumbers, tomatoes, olives, and onions. Salad was fresh, refreshing and relatively cheap -$6. We ended up sharing a Bogousta, a concoction of custard and cream cheese in a phylo dough shell. Tasted a bit like Baklava, but much lighter. Overall, a nice little cafe with reasonable prices and a pronounced Euro vibe.

I came out here to meet a fellow Yelper, and was surprised to find this place out on Milwaukee, Grand & Halsted - after the many times going out to Buddha Lounge - why hadn't I seen this place?!  Somehow the word intoxicated, comes to mind...   It's definitely felt like a European cafe with all the different foreigners sitting in here and chatting it up.  I love that multicultural vibe and feel of a place.  I ended up having an Italian sandwich and pasta as a side, and it was quite tasty and the perfect portion and we split the Bagousta.  I can't imagine two people splitting a whole one of these.  It was a great combination of a custard and those thin layers of crispy baklava flakes.  Yum!   I would like to come back and try some of the coffee here, because I just think that they would have some rich worldly flavor that I could possibly be missing out on...
Tons of space, good coffee, yummy/fat menu.

This place is excellent for brunch on the weekends. There is never a wait and the prices are reasonable. You gotta go and try their omelettes. Yes it does take 20 min to make because it's cooked in the oven, but it's so worth it. Or if you're in a hurry their croissant breakfast sandwiches are tasty too. The staff is friendly and it's super chill. I believe it also has Wi-Fi...

Iguana is a fun hang out cafe that is one of the only cafes I know that is open as late as bars. So If you feel like staying out late for tea or brownies, you should give this place a try.  It's very chill and the music selection sounds like European downbeat techno.   My usual order is green tea and a brownie sundae.

This was one of the first restaurants I acquainted myself with when I moved into the neighborhood 2 years ago.  I will admit to having an addiction to their breakfast sandwiches (especially on hangover mornings) and I often curse the Iguana because they don't open until 8:00 am.  Lunch and dinner are ok, I agree with Heather S., stay away from the salads.  But, overall, I look to Iguana for a quick and satiating breakfast on the go, or a coffee stop.
Try the latte........I did and I loved it. Plus, this is one of  a few place where the employees seem genuinely nice. I have yet to try the food but I love the lattes!
Yum...good  sandwiches from the menu or make your own as I do with jalapenos and their pasta hot or cold is delicious. A great lunch option for sure!!

I've always loved coming to this place to hang out, have a coffee, and a sandwich.  The waitresses are always a bit on the rude or lackluster side...I guess that is just in keeping with the Euro theme.  The food is great.  Atmosphere is wonderful although I kind of miss the tacky water fountain/fall thing they had going a few years ago.  I highly recommend this place for your afternoon caffeine fix.

One of my favorite hang-outs in the Chi- I lived in Lincoln Park for four years, but would make the trek down here because for Euro cafe ambiance and excellent food and drinks it is unparalleled.  The daytime atmosphere is laid back and conducive to happily whittling away the hours- it's a great place to study and also catch up with a friend over coffee- I highly recommend their hot chocolate!  Things liven up at night and it becomes a great place for any size group to relax, eat and enjoy the good company.  I've done all of the above at Iguana + sent one of my best friends off to Morocco in a giant party where we blocked off 1/4 of the restaurant & were informed (politely) that we could have called ahead of time to make reservations and they would have gladly obliged.  I've even played board games on the odd not-21-yet-with-the-worst-fake-ID-known-to-man night.  Now that spinach is no longer to be feared like the plague, their spinach-artichoke dip is ambrosia in appetizer form.  Their sandwiches are good too & I've never been disappointed with their drinks.  I have some of my best college memories in this place because in good company you relax so much that the hours just slip by!

I would definitely go back again.  Last Sunday, my mother and I had a tasty lunch at the Iguana.  We also enjoyed an impromptu screening of "Mr. and Mrs. Smith" on the Iguana's nice plasma television set.   I would give this one five stars if it weren't for its depressing location, but I guess that's part of its Euro meets Chicago charm.  Iguana is easily accessible via the Blue Line Grand Station or 65 Grand Bus to and from Navy Pier.  They also have parking lot at Halsted and Grand. As we approached the joint on a slushy sidewalk last Sunday, my mother noted the rather bleak streetscape.  "The city needs to do something about this intersection." I quickly reminded her that Iguana has a smoking section, which brought a smile to her face. The food is solid, tasty, and healthy.  It's a great place for coffee, espresso, and lattes.  I had the Mediterranean Sandwich, which was enjoyable and satisfying.  My mother had the Greek Sandwich, which was less satisfying by comparison, but nothing to complain about.  My dish was served with a small salad of mixed greens.  Mom's dish included a side of olives and other salty delights.   Atmosphere is definitely European.  Smoking gentlemen stand at the bar sipping espressos and taking heavy drags off cigarettes.  Some guy was enjoying a book with his feet up on the chair.  A young professional looking eastern European family sat with their baby in the non-smoking section.  Bookish 30 somethings and scruffy types seem to have taken up residence at the Iguana and the surrounding neighborhood.  Iguana's not really located in the heart of Chicago hipsterdom, but it's also not really located in the heart of anything.   Service was very, well, Eastern European.  I felt like I could have been in Budapest or Prague.  Waitresses are down to business, young, attractive, and on the move.  Not your typical, "How are you today?" Midwestern types, which can seem phony anyway.  I've never been at night, but I hear its a nice scene.

It's got a little bit of everything, in all the right doses. Thirsty? Decent selection of beverages. Hungry? Sandwiches and create-your-own dinner crepes do the trick for me here. Dessert? Delicious create-your-own dessert crepes are in order. Atmosphere? It's got a bit of a Euro-vibe to it. It's not a bad place to meet up with friends, or to have a casual business meeting.

When it picks up a little, usually at night any day of the week, it is a very hip scene.  Great energy in a non-pretentious environment.  Perfect place to meet a date or friend for coffee and a bite to eat.  I like the pasta dishes.  Cheap and filling.  During the day it's not too crowded so it could be a great place to study or get some work done  One thing that they need to add is a bottomless cup of coffee but I'm sure they don't need to because the place is usually busy.  Fast service always is a plus.

I've been there a few times. Service has mostly been friendly(not necessarily good) The food is good for the price. Nice place for a small meeting. Large parties would be a problem I suspect. Drinks are great. Free wi-fi.

I have been studying for my licensure exam in clinical psychology and this is a great place to study.  The staff is friendly and they let me sit there for hours on end.  They have great breakfast and lunch sandwiches and they have good red pepper hummus.  The coffee is good as well.  They play great music in here.  It does get pretty packed  during the weekend days.   Iguana draws a wide range of people and accommodates studying, simple lunch, and business meetings.   They do allow smoking in here, which can get a bit annoying depending on how many smokers are in the cafe at one time, but it sort of fits the European Bistro feel to this place. AND...it also attracts reality show celebrities like Josh Blue from Last Comic Standing (siting last weekend....).
Great food and service, cool environment.  One complaint- what's with the big smoking section?  Yuck.

Edited 3/18/08: I have to bump Iguana up to 5 stars now after I was finally able to try a dessert crepe.  I stumbled in here this past Saturday after drinking the morning away down the street at Emmit's in celebration of St. Pats.  After inhaling half of the goat cheese/marinara app and the majority of the chicken crepe I was supposedly "splitting", I went to town on a nutella, strawberry, and almond crepe ala mode.  It was absolute heaven.  I can hardly wait to go back and try it again. -------------------------------------------------------------------------- I've been meaning to visit this place for awhile, but I just recently made it in.  What a find!  Diverse little place, ranging from a coffee shop to a bar.  I wouldn't hesitate to come here with a group of friends for dinner or by myself with a book and my laptop. The food was great and reasonably priced.  I may become a regular here.

Love the atmosphere at the Iguana. My favorite is the meatloaf sandwhich. The espresso milkshake is very good. It is a great place to have a conversation with a friend. The music isn't deafening. People are friendly.

its not too often i come across a restaurant that i adore enough to eat there several times a week, but this is one of them.  let me state for the record: i really, really, REALLY love iguana.  of course, i may be a bit biased, since my boy brought me here for our first date.  regardless, iguana has an amazingly warm vibe.  its very euro, but not the least bit pretentious.  they usually play a nice mix of techno and trance, which keeps the energy upbeat.  however, its chill enough to comfortably relax with friends (or by yourself), read a book or simply people watch.  the menu is so reasonably priced...especially for the area. they offer nice size portions and the quality of food is consistent (not to mention delicious).  my personal favorite dish is the spring salad with smoked salmon...i'm addicted to it!  they have awesome soups and a variety of dipping-type appetizers.  but the crepes.  oh, the crepes are from heaven.  select from a bunch of yummy ingredients to make your own fluffy pocket of goodness.  mmmm...nutella!!!  they also have a full bar in case you need a little alcohol fix.  i'm a tea person, so i usually opt for the green tea, however the black current just might be even better.  oh, and don't pass on dessert either...i recommend the bougatsa for something a bit out of the ordinary.

I was beyond excited to discover this cafe only about 15 minutes away from my office - a fantastic new lunch option.  While dining at Iguana Cafe, I almost forgot I was in Chicago due to the quant European Cafe feel.  The ambiance is charming, the food is delicious, service was fine and there's even a live iguana for character!  Computers for use in the front make this perfect for the studious types as well.  I would return in a minute for lunch, dinner or better yet, dessert (nutella crepes - how can I resist)?

Iguana Cafe is a great little coffee house. They are always renovating and updating the place. I come here for meetings or just to have the crab dip (amazing). The coffee is really good, but refills are full price. The wi-fi is not free and often times the staff is very un-friendly. It's been getting much better though recently. It's not too far away from me so I come here often. There are great tables to have productive meetings, though I find the big screen tv terribly distracting. They've been playing "City of Angels" the past three times I have visited. I really don't care for this movie, but I always find my eyes drawn to this huge screen. They take credit cards and have many tasty pastries and dinner items!

While the sandwiches are tasty and the coffee decent, watch out for the salads.  Every time I have ordered them (to go, btw) the greens have been old and slimy.  This problem has been going on for over the past year.  I wish they would purchase fresher produce.    Nice atmosphere.  The servers can be a bit snooty at times.  Wish they were a bit more friendly.

Such a delightful cafe, with a reasonably priced menu. Delicious spinach and artichoke dip (although it's hard to go wrong ) and good mocha frappes. Salads leave a little to be desired. The wait staff are friendly and helpful; I was reading there once and a waiter asked if I would like some better light, and promptly rearranged for me. Great Europeanesque atmosphere that includes a live iguana and red telephone booth. Only real downside is the pounding techno beat that makes intimate conversation and concentration a bit difficult.

Oh come on!!! Give me one reason why I should not go there, eat a delicious crepe, chill on my laptop, glance at wonderful people surrounding me and not pay a fortune. This super place is my second home! Take it from a picky Greek...

If want good quality food (european cafe-type fare), at great prices, a cozy setting, and friendly servers, then check out Iguana Cafe.  The salads/paninis/crepes are great, and they also serve wine/coffee, etc, if you just want to sit and sip on something. A good place to bring your work/sit alone, but also a very nice spot to dine with a friend or two.  They're open pretty late (1am, i think), so there's no need to wrap up that conversation/finish that paragraph too quickly.

I went to Iguana with QJ and our Greek for dinner last night and I loooove this place.  It's perfect for lunch, dinner, or anything inbetween and their paninis and crepes are all tasty.  It has a great European feel to it, and it would be wonderful if they had patio space in the front for summertime. They have a nice wine selection in addition to coffees and other cafe drinks. I think I could live at the Iguana...I can see myself sitting in there for endless hours working on my stupid thesis....Then taking off my librarian sweater and letting my bun down to switch into night mode to enjoy dinner and a round of drinks with my crew.

My Greek brought me home some leftovers last week and I was craving them since.  Last nite we met there and had a chicken, tomato and provolone crepe, some tomato and mozz salad and the carrot cake is perfect.  From the bar section, to the coffee station, yummy all the way around, and I mean that. Seriously devine.  (and ya gotta love servers with accents) EDIT 3/31/07 I saw the yelp sticker on the door when i came in the other day. I love it here, my son loves it here, my friends love it here.  The servers are NOT snooty.  Just that hey're not from the South and wont "y'all" you on the way out the door.   If you cant handle the service here, you're just not cool. The food is still awesome as when I found it, and I still love coming here - even after having everything on the menu.

Cozy, yet spacious, the Iguana Cafe is an easy crowd pleaser that appeals to the studious, the artsy, and the girls or guys who just want to chit chat.    My only peeve is the smoking in combo w/ the lack of ventilation, but that's Chicago for ya.  The panini sandwiches are abso-freakin-lutely scrumptous.  My favorites include the meatloaf and the Italian - a perfect combination of provolone, oregano, olive oil, prosciutto, and nice crusty bread.  Don't forget to grab a brownie (a la mode, of course) and at that point, you will promise yourself to try a crepe next time.

This was a surprise find, in an area on Halsted that I rarely visit, other than passing by if I'm biking from work to Uk Village/Wicker. It's a great looking cafe with all the food amenities you'd want, cool space, interesting crowd, a live iguana, and good coffee.
